title-group.article-title: Modification of the existing maximum residue levels for potassium phosphonates in apricots and cherries
title-group.alt-title: Modification of the existing maximum residue levels for potassium phosphonates in apricots and cherries

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2025 European Food Safety Authority. EFSA Journal published by Wiley‐VCH GmbH on behalf of European Food Safety Authority.

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited and no modifications or adaptations are made.

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: In accordance with Article 6 of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005, the applicant Fitosanitarios de Bajo Riesgo AIE submitted a request to the competent national authority in France to modify the existing maximum residue levels (MRLs) for the active substance potassium phosphonates in apricots and cherries. The data submitted in support of the request were found to be sufficient to derive MRL proposals for the crops under assessment. Adequate analytical methods for enforcement are available to control the residues of potassium phosphonates in accordance with the residue definition ‘phosphonic acid and its salts expressed as phosphonic acid’ on commodities under consideration at the validated limit of quantification (LOQ) of 0.1 mg/kg. Based on the risk assessment results, EFSA concluded that the long‐term intake of residues resulting from the use of potassium phosphonates according to the reported agricultural practices is unlikely to present a risk to consumer health. The risk assessment shall be regarded as indicative because some MRL proposals derived by EFSA in the framework of the MRL review according to Articles 12 and 43 of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 require further consideration by risk managers.

p.mixed-citation: EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) , Bellisai, G. , Bernasconi, G. , Carrasco Cabrera, L. , Castellan, I. , del Aguila, M. , Ferreira, L. , Greco, L. , Jarrah, S. , Leuschner, R. , Mioč, A. , Nave, S. , Reich, H. , Ruocco, S. , Scarlato, A. P. , Simonati, A. , Szot, M. , Theobald, A. , Tiramani, M. , Verani, A. , & Zioga, E. (2025). Modification of the existing maximum residue levels for potassium phosphonates in apricots and cherries. EFSA Journal, 23 (2), e9232. 10.2903/j.efsa.2025.9232 39936156

fn.p: Approved: 17 January 2025
The declarations of interest of all scientific experts active in EFSA's work are available at https://open.efsa.europa.eu/experts

sec.title: SUMMARY
sec.p: In accordance with Article 6 of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005, Fitosanitarios de Bajo Riesgo AIE submitted an application to the competent national authority in France (evaluating Member State, EMS) to modify the existing maximum residue levels (MRLs) for the active substance potassium phosphonates in apricots and cherries.

The application, alongside the dossier containing the supporting data in IUCLID format, was submitted through the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) Central Submission System on 21 October 2022. The appointed EMS France assessed the dossier and declared its admissibility on 15 June 2023. Subsequently, following the implementation of the EFSA's confidentiality decision, the non‐confidential version of the dossier was published by EFSA and a public consultation launched on the dossier. The consultation aimed to consult stakeholders and the public on the scientific data, studies and other information part of, or supporting, the submitted application, in order to identify whether other relevant scientific data or studies are available. The consultation ran from 10 August 2023 to 31 August 2023. No additional data or comments were submitted in the framework of the consultation.

At the end of the commenting period, the EMS proceeded drafting the evaluation report, in accordance with Article 8 of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005, which was submitted to the European Commission and to EFSA on 7 October 2024. To accommodate for the intended southern Europe (SEU) uses of potassium phosphonates, the EMS proposed to raise the existing MRLs implemented in Regulation (EU) 2022/1324 for apricots and cherries from the limit of quantification (LOQ) of 2 to 50 mg/kg for apricots and to 80 mg/kg for cherries.
On 10 October 2024 the European Commission sent a mandate to EFSA to assess the application and the evaluation report as required by Article 10 of the MRL regulation.

EFSA identified points which needed further clarification and requested the EMS to address them. The EMS submitted a revised evaluation report to EFSA on 10 January 2025, which replaced the previously submitted evaluation report.

The current assessment is based on the conclusions derived by EFSA in the framework of Directive 91/414/EEC, the data evaluated under previous MRL assessments and the additional data provided by the EMS in the framework of this application. It should be noted that the modifications proposed by the joint MRL review for fosetyl and phosphonate and the various EFSA opinions issued after the joint review and combined in a scientific statement on MRLs for potassium phosphonates have been implemented in the Commission Regulation (EU) 2024/2619 which will supersede existing EU MRLs as from 29 April 2025 in addition, further MRL changes are applicable from PLAN/2024/2411 and are considered in the current assessment.
Based on the above‐mentioned information, the following conclusions are derived.

No metabolism studies are available for potassium phosphonates, however, the joint review of MRLs for fosetyl and phosphonates confirmed that the data from public literature provide sufficient evidence to address the metabolism of potassium phosphonates in plants. In primary crops and in rotational crops, phosphonic acid is expected to be the main residue. It is to be noted that phosphonic acid is also the common predominant metabolite of the active substances fosetyl‐Al and disodium phosphonate, approved for use in plant protection products in the EU.

Studies investigating the effect of processing on the nature of residues (hydrolysis studies) demonstrated that the relevant metabolite phosphonic acid is stable. As the proposed uses of potassium phosphonates are on permanent crops, investigations of residues in rotational crops are not required.

Based on the metabolic pattern identified in metabolism studies, hydrolysis studies and the toxicological relevance of phosphonic acid, the residue definitions for plant products were proposed in the joint MRL review for fosetyl and phosphonates as ‘phosphonic acid and its salts, expressed as phosphonic acid’ for both enforcement and risk assessment. The residue definitions are applicable to primary crops, rotational crops and processed products and cover residues in plant commodities also from the uses of fosetyl and disodium phosphonate.

EFSA concluded that for the crops assessed in this application, metabolism of potassium phosphonates in primary and in rotational crops, and the possible degradation in processed products has been sufficiently addressed and that the previously derived residue definitions are applicable.

Sufficiently validated analytical methods are available to monitor residues of phosphonic acid according to the residue definition for enforcement ‘phosphonic acid and its salts, expressed as phosphonic acid’ in the commodities under assessment with a limit of quantification (LOQ) of 0.1 mg/kg.

The available residue trials are sufficient to derive an MRL proposal of 50 mg/kg in apricots and 80 mg/kg for cherries in support of the intended SEU uses. It is noted that a higher MRL for apricots, 60 mg/kg, has been implemented in Commission Regulation (EU) 2024/2619, applicable as of 29 April 2025 and the lowering of this MRL is not proposed.

Processing factors (PFs) were derived from processing studies provided for the present assessment and can be considered for inclusion in Annex VI of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 as follows:
Apricots/nectar0.48Cherries/nectar0.77Peaches/nectar1.04
Apricots/jam0.44Cherries/jam0.66Peaches/jam0.59
Apricots/canned fruits0.56Cherries/canned fruits0.75Peaches/purée1.015
Peaches/canned fruits0.49
Residues of phosphonic acid in commodities of animal origin were not assessed since the crops under consideration in this MRL application are not considered as a relevant livestock fed item.

In the framework of the renewal of the approval for fosetyl, a revised lower acceptable daily intake (ADI) value of 1 mg/kg body weight (bw) per day has been derived for phosphonic acid. An acute reference dose (ARfD) was deemed unnecessary for phosphonic acid.

In the framework of the joint MRL review for fosetyl and phosphonates a comprehensive long‐term exposure assessment was performed considering residue data originating from the authorised uses of fosetyl, disodium phosphonate and potassium phosphonates, monitoring data as well as certain Codex maximum residue limits (CXLs) proposed to be taken over in the EU legislation for fosetyl‐Al and phosphonic acid. EFSA updated these calculations with the supervised trials median residue (STMR) values derived from the residue trials on apricots and cherries submitted under the present MRL application and with the STMRs derived for various crops in the EFSA opinions issued after the joint MRL review. The estimated long‐term dietary intake accounted for a maximum of 85% of ADI (NL toddler diet). The individual contribution of residues expected in apricots and cherries to the overall long‐term exposure accounted for ca 1% of the ADI.

EFSA concluded that residues of phosphonic acid resulting in food commodities from the proposed and existing uses of potassium phosphonates will not result in a consumer exposure exceeding the toxicological reference value and therefore are unlikely to pose a risk to consumers' health. The risk assessment shall be regarded as indicative because some MRL proposals derived by EFSA in the framework of the joint MRL review are implemented in the Regulation (EU) 2024/2619 and PLAN/2024/2411 on a tentative basis requiring submission of additional data.

EFSA concluded that the proposed use of potassium phosphonates on apricots and cherries will not result in a consumer exposure exceeding the toxicological reference value and therefore is unlikely to pose a risk to consumers' health. EFSA proposes to amend the existing MRLs as reported in the summary table below.

Full details of all end points and the consumer risk assessment can be found in Appendices B, C, D.
Code a
CommodityExisting EU MRL (mg/kg)EU MRL (mg/kg)Proposed EU MRL (mg/kg)Comment/justification
Reg. (EU)2022/1324Reg. (EU) 2024/2619 (applicable as from 29 April 2025) and PLAN/2024/2411
Enforcement residue definition: Phosphonic acid and its salts expressed as phosphonic acid b

The submitted data are sufficient to derive an MRL proposal of 50 mg/kg for the intended SEU use

Abbreviations: GAP, Good Agricultural Practice; MRL, maximum residue level; NEU, northern Europe; SEU, southern Europe. a
Commodity code number according to Annex I of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005. b
It is noted that the enforcement residue definition according to currently applicable Regulation (EU) 2022/1324 is ‘Fosetyl‐Al (sum of fosetyl, phosphonic acid and their salts, expressed as fosetyl)’. According to Regulation (EU) 2024/2619, this residue definition will be superseded on 29 April 2025 by the enforcement residue definition ‘Phosphonic acid and its salts expressed as phosphonic acid’. Thus, EFSA derived MRL proposals according to the new residue definition only, which will be applicable in due time.*
Indicates that the MRL is set at the limit of analytical quantification (LOQ).

sec.title: ASSESSMENT
sec.p: The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) received an application to modify the existing maximum residue levels (MRLs) for potassium phosphonates in apricots and cherries. The detailed description of the intended SEU uses of potassium phosphonates, which are the basis for the current MRL application, are reported in Appendix A.
Potassium phosphonates is the ISO common name for potassium hydrogen phosphonate (IUPAC). The chemical structures of the active substance and its main metabolites are reported in Appendix E.

Potassium phosphonates were evaluated in the framework of Directive 91/414/EEC 1 with France designated as rapporteur Member State (RMS); the representative use assessed was a foliar spray on grapes. The draft assessment report (DAR) prepared by the RMS has been peer reviewed. by EFSA (EFSA, 2012). The active substance potassium phosphonates was approved 2 for the use as fungicide on 1 October 2013. The process of the peer review for the renewal of the first approval has not yet been initiated.

The EU MRLs related to the use of potassium phosphonates are established in Annex IIIA of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005. 3 The current residue definition for enforcement is set as ‘Fosetyl‐Al (sum of fosetyl, phosphonic acid and their salts, expressed as fosetyl)’ but will be replaced to ‘phosphonic acid and its salts, expressed as phosphonic acid’ with the new regulation, Reg. (EU) 2024/2619, that will be applicable as of 29 April 2025. This residue definition is shared with other two active substances, fosetyl and disodium phosphonate, which are approved for uses in plant protection products in the EU. Hence, the existing MRLs cover not only the uses of potassium phosphonates, but also the uses of fosetyl and disodium phosphonate.

A joint review of MRLs for the active substances fosetyl, disodium phosphonate and potassium phosphonates in accordance with Articles 12 and 43 of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 (joint MRL review) was finalised in 2021 (EFSA, 2021c). After completion of the joint MRL review, EFSA issued several reasoned opinions on the modification of MRLs for these active substances (EFSA, 2021d, 2022a, 2022b, 2023, 2024). Furthermore, in 2022 EFSA was mandated from the Commission to issue a statement (EFSA, 2022c) combining the conclusions of the above‐mentioned scientific opinions published by EFSA in the time frame between June 2021 and January 2022 (EFSA, 2021a, 2021b, 2021c, 2021d, 2022a, 2022b). Finally, the proposals made in the joint MRL review and the following outputs have been considered in a recent MRL regulation, 4 Commission Regulation (EU) 2024/2619, which will supersede the currently applicable Regulation (EU) 2022/1324 as from 29 April 2025. Certain Codex maximum residue limits (CXLs) have also been taken over in the EU MRL legislation.

In accordance with Article 6 of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 and following the provisions set by the ‘Transparency Regulation’ (EU) 2019/1381, 5 the applicant Fitosanitarios de Bajo Riesgo AIE submitted on 21 October 2022 an application to the competent national authority in France, alongside the dossier containing the supporting data using the IUCLID format.

The appointed EMS France assessed the dossier and declared its admissibility on 15 June 2023. Subsequently, following the implementation of the EFSA's confidentiality decision, the non‐confidential version of the dossier was published by EFSA and a public consultation launched on the dossier. The consultation aimed to consult stakeholders and the public on the scientific data, studies and other information part of, or supporting, the submitted application, in order to identify whether other relevant scientific data or studies are available. The consultation ran from 10 August 2023 to 31 August 2023. No additional data nor comments were submitted in the framework of the consultation.

At the end of the commenting period, the EMS proceeded drafting the evaluation report, in accordance with Article 8 of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005, which was submitted to the European Commission and to EFSA on 7 October 2024. To accommodate for the intended SEU uses of potassium phosphonates, the EMS proposed to raise. The existing MRLs implemented in Regulation (EU) 2022/1324 for apricots and cherries from the limit of quantification (LOQ) of 2 to 50 mg/kg for apricots and to 80 mg/kg for cherries.
On 10 October 2024 the European Commission sent a mandate to EFSA to assess the application and the evaluation report as required by Article 10 of the MRL regulation.

EFSA identified points which needed further clarification and requested the EMS to address them. The EMS submitted a revised evaluation report to EFSA on 10 January 2025, which replaced the previously submitted evaluation report.

EFSA based its assessment on the evaluation report submitted by the EMS (France, 2024), the DAR and its addendum (France, 2005, 2012) prepared under Council Directive 91/414/EEC and the revised renewal assessment report (RAR) on fosetyl (France, 2018) prepared under Regulation (EU) No 1107/2009, 6 the Commission review report on potassium phosphonates (European Commission, 2022a), the conclusion on the peer review of the pesticide risk assessment of the active substances potassium phosphonates (EFSA, 2012) and fosetyl (EFSA, 2018b, 7 ), the joint review of maximum residue levels (MRLs) for fosetyl, disodium phosphonate and potassium phosphonates according to Articles 12 and 43 of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 (EFSA, 2021c), as well as the conclusion from the scientific statement on maximum residue levels for potassium phosphonates and the most recent EFSA reasoned opinions on potassium phosphonates (EFSA, 2022c, 2023, 2024).

For the present applications, the data requirements established in Regulation (EU) No 544/2011 8 and the guidance documents applicable at the date of submission of the application to the EMS are applicable (European Commission, 1997a, 1997b, 1997c, 1997d, 1997e, 1997f, 1997g, 2010, 2020, 2021, 2022b; OECD, 2014). The assessment is performed in accordance with the legal provisions of the Uniform Principles for the Evaluation and the Authorisation of Plant Protection Products adopted by Commission Regulation (EU) No 546/2011. 9
A selected list of end points of the studies assessed by EFSA in the framework of this MRL application including the end points of relevant studies assessed previously, is presented in Appendix B.

The evaluation report submitted by the EMS (France, 2024) and the exposure calculations using the EFSA Pesticide Residues Intake Model (PRIMo) are made publicly available as background documents to this reasoned opinion. 10

sec.title: Nature of residues and methods of analysis in plants
Nature of residues in primary crops
sec.p: No metabolism studies are available for potassium phosphonates. Nevertheless, during the EU pesticides peer review for approval of the active substance potassium phosphonates data from the public literature was concluded sufficient to address the metabolism in plants, which mainly involves the transformation of potassium phosphonate salts into phosphonic acid (EFSA, 2012). The metabolism of fosetyl‐Al and disodium phosphonate in primary crops was assessed in the framework of the EU pesticides peer review and the joint review of MRLs for fosetyl and phosphonates (EFSA, 2013, 2018b, 2021c). Phosphonic acid is also the predominant metabolite of the active substances fosetyl‐Al and disodium phosphonate.

Based on the available studies and considering the elementary nature of these active substances, the metabolic pathway of fosetyl, disodium and potassium phosphonates is expected to be similar in all crops, with phosphonic acid being the main compound present in the treated crops.

No further studies on the metabolism in primary crops were submitted in the present MRL application. For the intended uses, the metabolic behaviour of potassium phosphonates in primary crops is sufficiently addressed.

sec.title: Nature of residues in rotational crops
sec.p: As the proposed uses of potassium phosphonates are on permanent crops, investigations of residues in rotational crops are not required.

sec.title: Nature of residues in processed commodities
sec.p: The effect of processing on the nature of phosphonic acid, which is the main metabolite of potassium phosphonates, was investigated in the framework of the EU pesticides peer review for fosetyl (EFSA, 2018b) and the joint MRLs review of fosetyl and phosphonates (EFSA, 2021c). The available studies showed that phosphonic acid is hydrolytically stable under standard processing conditions representative of pasteurisation, baking/brewing/boiling and sterilisation.

sec.title: Analytical methods for enforcement purposes in plant commodities
sec.p: Sufficiently validated methods with independent laboratory validation (ILV) using high performance liquid chromatography coupled with tandem mass spectrometry (HPLC–MS/MS) are available to determine residues of phosphonic acid in high‐water content matrices (relevant for the crops under consideration), in high‐acid and high‐oil content matrices and dry commodities. The methods allow the monitoring of residues expressed in accordance with the residue definition for enforcement ‘phosphonic acid and its salts, expressed as phosphonic acid’ with a LOQ of 0.1 mg/kg (EFSA, 2021c).

Additionally, according to information provided by the EU Reference Laboratories (EURLs), during routine analysis, phosphonic acid can be enforced with an LOQ of 0.1 mg/kg in high‐water content commodities and with an LOQ of 0.2 mg/kg in high‐oil content and dry/high‐starch commodities by means of a single residue method (Quick Polar Pesticides Method – QuPPe) using liquid chromatography coupled with tandem mass spectrometry (LC–MS/MS) (EFSA, 2021c).

No information on extraction efficiency is available for these methods. However, due to the high solubility in water, extraction with solvents containing water can adequately dissolve potassium phosphonates (EFSA, 2023). Nevertheless, EFSA would recommend reconsidering this point in the peer review for the renewal of the active substance's approval.

In the current application, the applicant submitted an ILV study for an LC–MS/MS analytical method for data generation previously assessed by EFSA in the context of an MRL application in peaches (EFSA, 2018c; France, 2017, 2024). This analytical method and the ILV are sufficiently validated and deemed suitable for the enforcement of phosphonic acid with an LOQ of 0.5 mg/kg in high water content matrices in line with SANTE/2020/12830 (European Commission, 2021). To demonstrate the extraction efficiency of this method, the applicant conducted a cross‐validation study using incurred residues of potassium phosphonates in cherry samples. Since no specific metabolism studies are available for potassium phosphonates, the extraction solvent of this method (methanol) was compared to the solvent used in metabolism studies of the peer review of fosetyl (France, 2018), where water was used as a solvent system to extract residues from tomatoes. The metabolism studies used carbon‐labelled fosetyl, meaning that radioactive residues of phosphonic acid could not be directly quantified. Nevertheless, since phosphonic acid is a metabolite of fosetyl, EFSA considered the extraction efficiency of fosetyl in the metabolism studies in tomatoes as a proxy to evaluate the solvents' performance. In the metabolism studies on tomatoes, fruits were washed with water and then blended; no additional solvent was used on the liquid tomato samples or surface washes. This method recovered more than 70% of the total radioactive residues (TRRs) of fosetyl from the surface wash and tomato liquid phase. This recovery rate of fosetyl using water as a solvent was deemed acceptable. The applicant's results showed that similar levels of phosphonic acid were extracted from cherry fruits using either methanol (the monitoring method solvent) or water (the solvent from metabolism studies), with differences in the incurred residues extracted of less than 30%. Consequently, the extraction efficiency of the enforcement method using methanol is considered proven, as it meets the criteria outlined in the relevant technical guidance SANTE/2017/10632 (European Commission, 2022b).

Finally, in the current application, an LC–MS/MS method with ILV was submitted for enforcement in honey. The method is considered valid and allows for the enforcement of phosphonic acid at an LOQ of 0.05 mg/kg (France, 2024). It is noted that an MRL for honey was neither requested nor deemed necessary and an LC–MS/MS method with an LOQ for phosphonic acid of 0.05 mg/kg was already considered sufficiently validated for enforcement in honey according to the peer review for fosetyl (EFSA, 2018b, 2021c).

sec.title: Storage stability of residues in plants
sec.p: Data on the storage stability of phosphonic acid under frozen conditions were reported in the joint MRLs review of fosetyl and phosphonates (EFSA, 2021c). It was demonstrated that in high‐water content commodities (covering the crops under assessment), residues of phosphonic acid are stable for up to 25 months when stored under −18°C.
For the intended uses, the storage stability of the residues in plant matrices is sufficiently addressed.

sec.title: Proposed residue definitions
sec.p:
The EU pesticides peer review of potassium phosphonates (EFSA, 2012) and the joint MRLs review of fosetyl and phosphonates (EFSA, 2021c) proposed the following residue definitions for potassium phosphonates plant commodities:
–Residue definition for risk assessment: Phosphonic acid and its salts, expressed as phosphonic acid.
–Residue definition for enforcement: Phosphonic acid and its salts, expressed as phosphonic acid.

The residue definitions apply to primary crops, rotational crops, and processed products and cover residues in food and feed resulting from the use of other two active substances, fosetyl and disodium phosphonate, which are approved for use in plant protection products in the EU.

The proposed wording for the residue definitions reported above is different from the current applicable Regulation (Reg. (EU) 2022/1324): ‘Fosetyl‐Al (sum of fosetyl, phosphonic acid and their salts, expressed as fosetyl)’. Nevertheless, the residue definition proposed in the joint MRL review was implemented in the new regulation, Reg. (EU) 2024/2619, which is not yet applicable. Considering that measures implemented by Regulation (EU) 2024/2619 will be applicable as from 29 April 2025, EFSA derived the new MRL proposals according to the new residue definition.

sec.title: Magnitude of residues in primary crops
sec.p: GAP apricots and cherries outdoor, SEU, foliar application: 3 × 2.904 kg potassium phosphonates/ha; BBCH 32–91; interval between treatments 14 day; PHI 14 days.

To support the intended SEU uses in apricots and cherries, the applicant submitted six residue trials on apricots and 10 trials on cherries (France, 2024). The residue trials on cherries and apricots were conducted in diverse locations of Spain, Italy, Greece and southern France in 2020.

Additionally, to complement the dataset for apricots, eight previously evaluated residue trials on peaches and nectarines, compliant with the intended SEU GAP, were included (EFSA, 2018c). The applicant proposed to extrapolate the combined residue data set on apricots and peaches to apricots. According to the technical guidance, residue data from peaches and apricots (with at least 50% of the trials conducted on apricots) can be extrapolated to apricots (European Commission, 2020).
All trials were deemed independent and compliant with the intended GAP (France, 2024).

Fruit samples were analysed for phosphonic acid in line with the residue definitions for risk assessment and enforcement. Before analysis, the fruits were destoned, and the weights of both destoned samples and whole fruits were recorded. Residue levels in whole fruit were calculated using the fruit without stones/whole fruit weight ratio.

According to the assessment of the EMS, the analytical methods were sufficiently validated and fit for purpose (France, 2024) The extraction efficiency of the solvent used in the method, methanol, was demonstrated (see Section 1.1.4). Furthermore, the trial samples were stored under conditions that ensured sample integrity throughout the study.
The number of trials is sufficient to derive an MRL proposal of 80 mg/kg for the intended use of potassium phosphonates in cherries and 50 mg/kg in apricots.

sec.title: Magnitude of residues in rotational crops
sec.p: As the proposed uses of potassium phosphonates are on permanent crops, investigations of residues in rotational crops are not required.

sec.title: Magnitude of residues in processed commodities
sec.p: To investigate the effect of industrial processing on the magnitude of residues, several processing trials were performed with the crops under consideration: two studies on apricots, two on cherries and four studies on peaches (France, 2024). Samples of raw agricultural commodity (RAC) were taken from field trials, where fruits received foliar spray (2.9 kg a.s./ha) and drip irrigation (7.3 kg a.s./ha) applications. Samples were collected 14 days after the treatment. Residue levels of phosphonic acid were analysed in the RAC (whole fruit) and in the processed commodities. The studies were considered valid according to the applicable guidance (European Commission, 1997d).
Fruits were processed into nectar, jam, purée (just apricots and peaches) and canned fruits.

In the processed commodities of apricots and cherries, no concentration of phosphonic acid residues was observed (PF < 1). The number of submitted studies, according to applicable guidance document is not sufficient, as three trials would be generally required (European Commission, 1997d). However, since no concentration of residues is observed across various processed commodities and the difference between two PFs per processed commodity is less than 50% (with exception of apricot puree), EFSA considered that median PFs can still be derived under these circumstances and the lack of one additional trial was not considered as a data gap. The difference between derived processing factors was more than 50% in apricot purée, so an additional trial may be necessary to derive a consistent processing factor according to OECD No. 508 and to fulfil the data requirement for one additional trial according to the applicable EU guidance document (European Commission, 1997d; OECD, 2008). For apricot purée, therefore, a robust processing factor could not be derived.
The median processing factor for peaches revealed a slight concentration of phosphonic acid residues in nectar and purée (PF 1.04 and 1.015), but not in jam and canned fruits (PF < 1).

On the basis of above‐mentioned considerations, robust processing factors could be derived for all processed commodities except for apricot purée. EFSA considers it appropriate to recommend their inclusion in Annex VI of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005.

sec.title: Proposed MRLs
sec.p: The available data are considered sufficient to derive MRL proposals and risk assessment values for the commodities under evaluation. It is noted that a higher MRL of 60 mg/kg than the proposed MRL of 50 mg/kg based on the intended use has been implemented for apricots in the Reg. (EU) 2024/2619 (applicable as from 29/04/2024). In Section 3, EFSA assessed whether residues on these crops resulting from the intended uses are likely to pose a consumer health risk.

sec.title: RESIDUES IN LIVESTOCK
sec.p: Not relevant as apricots and cherries are not considered as a relevant fed item to livestock according to the current guidance (OECD, 2013).

sec.title: CONSUMER RISK ASSESSMENT
sec.p: EFSA performed a dietary risk assessment for the residues of phosphonic acid using revision 3.1 of the EFSA PRIMo (EFSA, 2018a, 2019). This exposure assessment model contains food consumption data for different sub‐groups of the EU population and allows the acute and chronic exposure assessment to be performed in accordance with the internationally agreed methodology for pesticide residues (FAO, 2016).
Considering the toxicological profile of the active substance, a short‐term dietary risk assessment was not required.

In the framework of the joint MRL review of fosetyl and phosphonates (EFSA, 2021c) a comprehensive long‐term exposure assessment was performed taking into account consumer exposure to residues originating from the plant protection uses of fosetyl (formulated as its aluminium salt), disodium phosphonate and potassium phosphonates. In addition, the available monitoring data were considered to account for residues of phosphonic acid originating from other sources (such as fertilisers, plant strengtheners, manure, soil amendments). This assessment took into account as well Codex MRLs derived for fosetyl‐Al and phosphonic acid.

EFSA updated these calculations with the relevant median residue values (STMR) from pulp derived for apricots and cherries from the residue trials submitted in support of the present MRL application and with the STMRs derived for various crops and commodities in the EFSA opinions adopted following the joint MRL review (EFSA, 2021d, 2022a, 2022b, 2023, 2024) in line with the EFSA statement (EFSA, 2022c). The input values used in the exposure calculations are summarised in Appendix D.1.

The highest chronic exposure was calculated at 85% of the ADI (Dutch toddler diet). The individual contribution of residues in apricots and cherries to the overall long‐term exposure to phosphonic acid were low with apricots contributing to 0.61% of ADI and cherries to 1.03% of ADI. Further details on the results of the consumer risk assessment are presented in Appendix B.3.

EFSA concludes that the existing uses of fosetyl and phosphonates (previously assessed in the joint MRL review and assessments following the MRL review) and new proposed uses of potassium phosphonates on apricots and cherries will not result in a consumer exposure exceeding the toxicological reference value and therefore is unlikely to pose a risk to consumers' health. The risk assessment shall be regarded as indicative, because certain MRL proposals derived by EFSA in the framework of the joint MRL review are implemented in the Regulation (EU) 2024/2411 on a tentative basis requiring submission of additional data.
For further details on the exposure calculations, a screenshot of the Report sheet of the PRIMo is presented in Appendix C.

sec.title: CONCLUSION AND RECOMMENDATIONS
sec.p: The data submitted in support of this MRL application were found to be sufficient to derive an MRL proposal of 50 mg/kg for apricots and 80 mg/kg for cherries. It is noted that the MRL of 60 mg/kg implemented for apricots in the Reg. (EU) 2024/2619 (applicable as from 29/04/2024) is higher than the MRL proposal of 50 mg/kg derived under the present assessment. The lowering of the MRL for apricots is not proposed.

EFSA concluded that the proposed use of potassium phosphonates on apricots and cherries will not result in a consumer exposure exceeding the toxicological reference value and therefore is unlikely to pose a risk to consumers' health.
The MRL recommendations are summarised in Appendix B.4.

Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) No 369/2013 of 22 April 2013 approving the active substance potassium phosphonates, in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning the placing of plant protection products on the market, and amending the Annex to Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) No 540/2011 OJ L 111, 23.4.2013, pp. 39–42.

Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 of the Parliament and of the Council of 23 February 2005 on maximum residue levels of pesticides in or on food and feed of plant and animal origin and amending Council Directive 91/414/EEC. OJ L 70, 16.3.2005, pp. 1–16.
For an overview of all MRL Regulations on this active substance, please consult: https://ec.europa.eu/food/plant/pesticides/eu‐pesticides‐database/start/screen/mrls.

Regulation (EU) 2019/1381 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 June 2019 on the transparency and sustainability of the EU risk assessment in the food chain and amending Regulations (EC) No 178/2002, (EC) No 1829/2003, (EC) No 1831/2003, (EC) No 2065/2003, (EC) No 1935/2004, (EC) No 1331/2008, (EC) No 1107/2009, (EU) 2015/2283 and Directive 2001/18/EC, PE/41/2019/REV/1. It is noted that the Standing Committee on Plants, Animals, Food and Feed (SCoPAFF) meeting endorsed the new recommended ADI value (1 mg/kg body weight (bw) per day) in its meeting of 24–25 May 2023 (Sante.g.3(2023)8536936 Standing Committee on Plants, Animals, Food and Feed Section Phytopharmaceuticals – Legislation 24–25 May 2023 PT.A 19.02. Revised Review Report not yet published online).

app.label: APPENDIX A
app.title: Summary of intended GAP triggering the amendment of existing EU MRLs

tr.th: Pests or Group of pests controlled
Range of growth stages & season c

fn.p: Abbreviations: a.s., active substance; GAP, Good Agricultural Practice; MRL, maximum residue level; MS, Member State; NEU, northern European Union; SEU, southern European Union; SL, soluble liquid.
Outdoor or field use (F), greenhouse application (G) or indoor application (I).
CropLife International Technical Monograph no 2, 7th Edition. Revised March 2017. Catalogue of pesticide formulation types and international coding system.

Growth stage range from first to last treatment (BBCH Monograph, Growth Stages of Plants, 1997, Blackwell, ISBN 3‐8263‐3152‐4), including, where relevant, information on season at time of application.
PHI – minimum pre‐harvest interval.

sec.label: B.1.1
sec.title: Nature of residues and analytical methods for enforcement purposes in plant commodities

sec.label: B.1.1.1
sec.title: Metabolism studies, analytical methods and residue definitions in plants

td.p: No experimental studies submitted for potassium phosphonates.

The EU pesticides peer review and the joint review of MRLs for fosetyl and phosphonates concluded that, given the elementary nature of potassium phosphonates and according to the available data from public literature, the main residue resulting from the foliar and soil applications of potassium phosphonates in plants is phosphonic acid (EFSA, 2012, 2021c)

tr.td: Bare soil application of non‐radiolabelled phosphonic acid at a target concentration of 4.9 mg/kg

td.p: No experimental studies submitted for potassium phosphonates
Bridging data on studies with fosetyl not conducted with radiolabelled material (EFSA, 2018b) considered sufficient to assess the nature of potassium phosphonates in rotational crops (EFSA, 2021c)

tr.td: According to experimental studies performed with phosphonic acid provided in the EU pesticides peer review of fosetyl (EFSA, 2018b), phosphonic acid is hydrolytically stable (EFSA, 2021c)
Baking, brewing and boiling (60 min, 100°C, pH 5)
Phosphonic acid and its salts expressed as phosphonic acid
Phosphonic acid and its salts expressed as phosphonic acid
Phosphonic acid and its salts expressed as phosphonic acid
Phosphonic acid and its salts expressed as phosphonic acid
Phosphonic acid and its salts expressed as phosphonic acid
Phosphonic acid and its salts expressed as phosphonic acid
Phosphonic acid and its salts expressed as phosphonic acid
Phosphonic acid and its salts expressed as phosphonic acid
Phosphonic acid and its salts expressed as phosphonic acid
Peach jam, puree, nectar and canned peaches

sec.label: B.1.2.1
sec.title: Summary of residues data from the supervised residue trials

tr.th: Residue levels observed in the supervised residue trials (mg/kg)

tr.td: RD‐Mo/RD‐RA: Phosphonic acid and its salts, expressed as phosphonic acid

Residue trials performed on apricots and peaches/nectarines (underlined) compliant with GAP (France, 2024). Extrapolation from a combined data set of apricots and peaches to apricots acceptable (European Comission, 2020)
Residue trials performed on cherries compliant with GAP (France, 2024)

fn.p: Abbreviations: GAP, Good Agricultural Practice; Mo, monitoring; MRL, maximum residue level; RA, risk assessment; RD, residue definition.
SEU: Outdoor trials conducted in southern Europe.
Highest residue. The highest residue for risk assessment refers to the whole commodity and not to the edible portion. Residues derived from pulp were used in the risk assessment.
Supervised trials median residue. The median residue for risk assessment refers to the whole commodity and not to the edible portion. Residues derived from pulp were used in the risk assessment.
Conversion factor to recalculate residues according to the residue definition for monitoring to the residue definition for risk assessment.
Abbreviations: PF, processing factor.

It is noted that, according to applicable data requirements three processing studies are necessary to establish a robust processing factor (PF) (European Commission, 1997d). However, given that a reduction of residues is observed among all processed commodities and since the difference between both PFs is less than 50%, EFSA considered that a robust PF can still be derived on the basis of 2 studies.

The difference between main processed products was more than 50%, so an additional trial is in principle required to derive a robust processing factor according to EU guidelines (European Commission, 1997d) and OECD No. 508 (OECD, 2008).

sec.label: B.2
sec.title: Residues in livestock
sec.p: Not relevant.

sec.label: B.3
sec.title: Consumer risk assessment
sec.p: Acute consumer risk assessment not relevant since no ARfD has been considered necessary (EFSA, 2018b).

tr.th: EU MRL (mg/kg) Reg. (EU) 2024/2619 (applicable as from 29 April 2025) and PLAN/2024/2411

tr.td: Enforcement residue definition: Phosphonic acid and its salts expressed as phosphonic acid b

td.p: The submitted data are sufficient to derive an MRL proposal of 50 mg/kg for the intended SEU use
The intended use would require raising of the existing EU MRL currently set at the LOQ
It is noted that a higher MRL of 60 mg/kg will be applicable for apricots as from 29 April 2025 according to Reg. (EU) 2024/2619. Lowering of this MRL is not proposed

tr.td: The submitted data are sufficient to derive an MRL proposal for the SEU use. Risk for consumers is unlikely

fn.p: Abbreviations: GAP, Good Agricultural Practice; MRL, maximum residue level; NEU, northern Europe; SEU, southern Europe.
Commodity code number according to Annex I of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005.

It is noted that the enforcement residue definition according to currently applicable Regulation (EU) 2022/1324 is ‘Fosetyl‐Al (sum of fosetyl, phosphonic acid and their salts, expressed as fosetyl)’. According to Regulation (EU) 2024/2619, this residue definition will be superseded on 29 April 2025 by the enforcement residue definition ‘Phosphonic acid and its salts expressed as phosphonic acid’. Thus, EFSA derived MRL proposals according to the new residue definition only, which will beapplicable in due time.
Indicates that the MRL is set at the limit of analytical quantification (LOQ).

app.label: APPENDIX D
app.title: Input values for the exposure calculations

tr.td: Risk assessment residue definition: phosphonic acid and its salts, expressed as phosphonic acid
Spring onions/green onions and Welsh onions
Cress and other sprouts and shoots
Other lettuce and other salad plants
Other commodities of plant or animal origin

Input values as derived in the joint review of MRLs for fosetyl, disodium phosphonate and potassium phosphonates according to Articles 12 and 43 of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 and report in appendix D2 of EFSA (2021c)

fn.p: Abbreviation: STMR‐RAC, supervised trials median residue in raw agricultural commodity.

Figures in the table are rounded to two digits, but the calculations are normally performed with the actually calculated values (which may contain more digits). To reproduce dietary burden calculations, the unrounded values need to be used.
MRL derived from a GAP evaluated at EU level for fosetyl in the MRL review (EFSA, 2021c). STMR derived from the current application (France, 2024).
Abbreviations: InChiKey, International Chemical Identifier Key; IUPAC, International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry; SMILES, simplified molecular‐input line‐entry system.
The metabolite name in bold is the name used in the conclusion.
